definition: A serve that lands in the opponent's court without being touched.
Serve that directly scores a point without being touched.
Altering the hitting approach based on set location.
Passing the ball while both feet are off the ground.
Player who stabilizes a rotation or formation.
A spike directed diagonally across the court.
A block aimed at covering diagonal attacks.
Reading the opponent’s play to react early.
The steps a hitter takes before jumping for an attack.
The motion of the arm during a spike or attack.
Area near the net from which attackers hit the ball.
An attack made from behind the 3-meter line.
Defensive positioning and play from the back row.
A tip over the net aimed toward the backcourt.
Attack executed from the back row, behind the 3-meter line.
Defensive positioning behind front-row players.
Defensive dig executed in the backcourt.
Teammate supporting coverage after a primary play.
Spike aimed near the back boundary line.
Defending near the back boundary line.
Serve aimed along or near the back boundary line.
The skill of controlling the ball during passes, sets, and attacks.
Directing the ball to a strategic spot on the court.
Regaining control of a ball after an opponent’s attack.
Following the ball visually to anticipate its trajectory.
The speed at which the ball travels.
Standard defensive positioning before an attack.
A defensive play at the net to stop or deflect an attack.
When multiple players help to successfully block an attack.
Positioning to cover a block assisted by teammates.
Positioning teammates to recover balls after a block attempt.
Practice steps and movement for effective blocking.
A block that deflects the ball out of bounds off the opponent’s attack.
Extending hands over the net to effectively block an attack.
The degree hands extend over the net to cover an attack.
Training to extend hands over the net effectively.
Movement from blocking to defensive coverage.
A player attempting to stop or redirect an opponent’s attack at the net.
Angle formed by hands and arms to cover attackers.
Exercise to improve timing and hand positioning in blocks.
Spike directed to strike the opponent’s court near the sideline or endline.
Serve that curves sharply and unpredictably in the air.
A powerful spike aimed at scoring a point.
A high-powered spike targeting a weak spot in defense.
Pass that first touches the floor before reaching a teammate.
A serve that hits the floor once before reaching the opponent.
Defensive positioning after an opponent’s surprise attack.
Serve that disrupts the opponent’s formation.
Alignment of blockers to cover maximum net area.
Setting the ball using a forearm pass.
Communication among players regarding ball direction or play strategy.
Verbal communication to cover an opponent’s attack.
Illegal handling of the ball where it is momentarily held.
Quickly redirecting the ball after contact.
Middle player specializing in blocking attacks at the net.
Positioning of the middle hitter during rotation.
A set delivered to the middle hitter.
A serve that hits the ceiling and lands in play on the opponent’s side.
Moving quickly to reach a ball that is difficult to reach.
Spike with downward slicing motion for sharp drop.
Key play executed under high-pressure situations.
Bringing hands together at the net to cover more area.
Positioning to recover balls deflected off a teammate’s attack or block.
A ball hit diagonally across the court from the hitter’s position.
Diagonal trajectory of an attack from hitter to court corner.
A pass delivered diagonally across the court to a teammate.
Rotation that temporarily positions players outside their usual zone.
Block executed quickly to intercept a fast attack.
Set delivered under pressure with minimal room for error.
A spin serve causing the ball to curve in flight.
Serve with spin causing it to cut sharply sideways.
Spike with a sharp angled direction.
Defending balls near the back boundary line.
A serve aimed near the opponent’s backline.
Soft attack directed toward the opponent’s backcourt.
Area where defenders are positioned to recover blocks or digs.
Exercise focused on improving digs, passes, and coverage.
Player specialized in defensive skills, usually back row.
All actions intended to prevent the opponent from scoring.
Attack executed later than usual to deceive blockers.
Set intentionally delayed to alter hitter timing.
Approach to the net from an angle rather than straight on.
Defensive positioning along diagonal lines of the court.
A defensive move to prevent the ball from hitting the floor.
Positioning after a teammate digs the ball.
Defensive action where the player dives to reach a low ball.
Two front-row players attempting to block an attack together.
Two contacts with the ball in succession, usually a fault.
Accidental two-touch pass, usually a fault.
When a player contacts the ball twice consecutively, usually considered a fault.
Two rotations occurring rapidly due to substitutions or errors.
Two attackers hitting simultaneously to confuse blockers.
Serve followed immediately by a teammate’s aggressive play.
Fast, low-trajectory spike aimed at the opponent’s floor.
Set delivered with speed and minimal height for fast attacks.
Hard-driven spike aimed at the opponent’s court.
Defensive alignment to handle soft tips or off-speed balls.
Practice positioning for defending soft attacks.
Serve that drops quickly after crossing the net to catch opponents off guard.
Setter delivers the ball before the attacker reaches optimal timing.
Jumping before reaching optimal approach timing.
Spike aimed at the sideline or edge of the court.
Defensive positioning near sideline areas.
Attack executed to recover from a poor set or situation.
Recovering a ball that would otherwise hit out-of-bounds.
Foot leaving the ground during a jump or spike.
Longer step pattern before hitting the ball to gain power.
Blocking where arms fully extend over the net to intercept the ball.
Maximum arm extension to reach ball during block or attack.
Shoulder rotation outward to increase hitting range.
Pretending to cover one area while shifting to another.
Setter fakes a set to mislead blockers.
Deceptive action by setter pretending to set, then hitting.
Deceptive movement pretending to attack but not hitting.
Spike made while jumping backward to maintain balance.
Light, soft serve aimed to float unpredictably.
Set intended to prepare a specific hitter for attack.
Correct placement of players during offensive or defensive plays.
Ability to observe court positioning and anticipate plays.
Optional or non-primary set to maintain offense continuity.
Block where hands flip to redirect the ball.
Serve with a flicking motion for sudden change in direction.
A quick set with a slight flick of the wrist.
Techniques used to save the ball while diving or sliding.
Completion motion of the arm or hand after a hit or serve.
Driving the ball toward the opponent’s court aggressively.
Ball returned without attack pressure, usually after a weak hit.
Positioning to recover balls deflected off the front row.
Practice positioning to recover balls in front of blockers.
Attack executed by a front-row player near the net.
Attack made by a player positioned in the front row.
Setter positioned in the front row who can attack legally.
Alignment of attackers near the net in a straight line.
Attack aimed at open spaces between blockers.
Positioning to cover open spaces left by teammates.
Practice positioning to cover open areas between defenders.
Soft attack aimed at exploiting gaps in the opponent’s defense.
A point that will win the game if scored.
Defensive play aimed at protecting the back boundary line.
Set that results in a point-winning attack.
Primary attacker relied on in critical plays.
Defensive recovery of a ball rolling or bouncing on the court.
Recovering balls near the floor, often requiring dives or rolls.
Block intended to deflect rather than fully stop the attack.
Partial block by a single player covering only part of the net.
Set delivered with less than full height for a quick attack.
Soft attack partially over the net, landing just past blockers.
Correct alignment of hands during passing, setting, or blocking.
Proper technique of setting the ball using fingers.
Set delivered with a guiding motion resembling a handoff.
Powerful spike aimed to overwhelm defense.
Powerful serve aimed to overpower opponents.
Direction at which the ball is struck over the net.
Exercise designed to improve attacking techniques.
Movement of feet to optimize attack position and timing.
Path along which a spike travels.
Stance and location used to execute an attack.
Plan for targeting specific areas or weaknesses on the opponent’s court.
Area of the court where attacks are concentrated.
Combination of single and double block strategies.
Attack directed toward the middle of the opponent’s court.
Middle front-row attacker.
Attack aimed diagonally toward the court’s outer side.
Spike directed diagonally from the inside to the outside court.
Gaining control of an opponent’s pass or set.
Practice exercises for intercepting opponent passes or attacks.
Quick, short pass to redirect the ball efficiently.
Serve with erratic movement to confuse receivers.
Steps taken before jumping for attack or block.
Spike executed while airborne.
Block made while jumping to reach the ball above the net.
Exercise to improve jumping ability and timing for attacks or blocks.
A serve combining a jump and no spin for unpredictable motion.
A set performed while the setter jumps to reach higher.
A serve where the player jumps before hitting the ball.
Soft attack executed while airborne.
Exercises to enhance vertical leap for blocking and attacking.
Crucial attack intended to secure a point.
Critical area on the court, often near the net or attack zones.
Hit made slightly after the optimal timing to confuse blockers.
A set delivered slightly later than normal, disrupting timing.
Attack executed slightly after the expected timing to confuse blockers.
Primary offensive attacker in the lineup.
Approach along a straight path to the net.
A block aimed to stop a ball going along the sideline.
Defending balls aimed along the sideline.
Exercise to improve attacking or defending along the court lines.
A spike directed along the sideline.
Spike directed straight along the sideline.
Arrangement of players for service or rotation.
Relaxed steps toward the ball to maintain balance and control.
A ball not under control by any player.
Serve that lacks speed or placement, easier to receive.
Steps for attack or set with lower body position.
Block executed with minimal jump, emphasizing hand position.
Soft attack landing close to the net.
Defensive system where each player marks a specific opponent.
Attack made by a middle hitter close to the net.
A block executed by the middle front-row player.
Exercise for positioning behind the middle blocker or hitter.
Player positioned in the middle front row who attacks and blocks.
Alignment of middle hitters for quick attack execution.
Soft attack by the middle hitter over blockers.
